Member since: May 15, 2007 Total points: 4,142 (Level 4) Add Contact Block Yes, they can legally do that. 5 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes 1 person rated this as good by Problem Child Member since: November 29, 2006 Total points: 12,021 (Level 6) Add Contact Block This is a BIg pet peeve of mine. The answer is NO. You have purchased that property and it is now yours. They have zero right to search you.Period. I refuse all the time.A police officer couldn't look in your bag without a warrant or probable cause. I sure as hell am not letting some 5 dollar and hour wanna be look. If they think you are shoplifting, they can detain you and search you but they have better have evidence or they will be the ones arrested when the police arrive. I consider it insulting and essentially accusing every customer of being a shoplifter. Plus, if you watch them, they very rarely actually look, which means they are wasting my time. A store has no more right to search you or detain you then any other person. The problem is people accept it and go along with it. These are probably also the same people who cry about civil rights and the patriot act, yet they let some square badge violate their rights without blinking and eye! And NO they do not have any legal right to stop you for any reason except to make a citizens arrest, like any citizen can do. Bottom line, we have a constitution that prohibits unlawful search and seizure. BY ANYONE! There is no addendum that says target or Wal Mart can search you. They can not. If they are stopping you because they suspect you of shop lifting, that is a totally different story. To just stand there and ask to see everyones bag, while not illegal, is not required. It is purely voluntary. I have never shown my receipt or purchases (except at Cosco and the like) and I have never been detained, chased etc. Why? Because they can't without.....class? Member since: June 21, 2007 Total points: 414 (Level 2) Add Contact Block No way. Once you purchase the item it is YOUR PROPERTY. They don't have any more right to search the bag than they do to strip search you unless you have signed a contract allowing them to do so, which could happen if you are using a discount warehouse like Costco. Not do they have any right to detain you. If they do it is a form of kidnapping known as unlawful imprisonment.
People put up with this because they are used to it. But in fact the only right a store has is to request that you leave their premises and never return. It they try something more call the cops. 5 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes 2 people rated this as good by Kacy H Member since: June 13, 2006 Total points: 5,156 (Level 5) Add Contact Block If you think they are singling you out because of race, feel free to get the information of their district manager, and their corporate office information.

They choose to do so, knowing that most people do not have the funds to provide their own lawers and will often drop the case.
Where I worked, the only time we were allowed to stop individuals if: 1. we see what they took 2. where they consealed it. 3. did not break line of sight the remaining time they were in the store.
In stead we were incouraged to be extra helpful to those individuals, giving them extensive personalized attention while they were shoping.

If it is a random check, and you have nothing to hide, it costs you nothing except a minute of your time. If you refuse, they can't accost you unless someone has actually seen what appeared to be a theft by you. However, it is private property. They could tell you you are banned, and not to come back if they deem you undesirable. They could post a photo with security, and if you come back you could be arrested for trespassing. Does it happen often? No, of course not, it isn't really good for business. One of our stores get around the problem by taping shut any bags people bring into the store, and stapling shut the bags of purchases. The only bags searched are those that people won't let them tape, or bags that are taped, then re-opened (that looks really suspicious).
And don't you just love how people talk about"rights"? Member since: August 10, 2007 Total points: 3,906 (Level 4) Add Contact Block YES 5 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes by ♥Sarai♥ Member since: July 10, 2007 Total points: 3,040 (Level 4) Add Contact Block Yes. It is legal for them to check your bags. The only thing they cannot do is detain you (if you have not stolen anything). The law gives retailers the right to inspect bags at any given time.
EDIT**
I have worked in Loss Prevention for 5 years now and we get paid no where near 5 something an hour! Are you kidding me!! Try 40k. I haven't made 5 something an hour since I was in high school. To work in LP, you are trusted with highly sensitive information and must be credible. They are never going to hire someone into LP starting at no less than 28k. The retailer or its employees will NOT be arrested for a"bad stop". Even if you were detained. The only one who will be arrested is the shoplifter. Any law abiding citizen should not be offended by a LP investigator checking their purchase or receipt. Don't forget, you are on private property. A retailer that is not like Costco, Sam's or Fry's and does not have associates standing at the doors with a highlighter, will not just stand at the door checking everyone's bags for no reason. We simply do not have time for that anyways. We are more interested in Internal theft, being that is the greater cause of shrink.
Oh--I see references to"security people". What a stereotype. Loss Prevention is not Security. We do not wear uniforms and carry flashlights driving around in golf carts. Two totally different jobs!
One last thing...You can file a lawsuit if you want if you have been detained without a shoplifting incident, however, be prepared to"stand in line"to never see a courtroom. Source(s): I work in loss prevention. I have a bachelor's degree in Criminal Justice.
